CQ: What data formats are used in the deep learning pipeline?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The data formats used in the deep learning pipeline include multitemporal remote sensing data, such as MODIS-derived NDVI and LAI images collected in 2009, and plant species richness data from South Korea. The remote sensing data are co-registered and resampled to 30-arcseconds from 15-arcseconds of the original sources. The plant species richness data from South Korea are used to estimate potential plant species richness patterns for North Korea using a state-of-the-art DL approach.
CQ Ground Truth: we estimated plant species richness in South Korea by combining the 1574 species‚Äô suitability estimations from species distribution models at a resolution of 30-arcseconds. We then developed a DL-based species richness model using the species richness results from South Korea and a time-series of MODIS-driven NDVI and LAI, which were resampled to 30-arcseconds from 15-arcseconds of the original sources.

We then developed a DL-based species richness model using the species richness results from South Korea and a time-series of MODIS-driven NDVI and LAI, which were resampled to 30-arcseconds from 15-arcseconds of the original sources.

CQ: How was raw data collected in terms of methods and tools?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The raw data for this study was collected using remote sensing data and plant species occurrence records. The remote sensing data was collected using multitemporal Landsat 8 images, which were preprocessed using the Google Earth Engine platform. The plant species occurrence records were collected from the Korea National Arboretum, the National Institute of Biological Resources, and the Korea Forest Service. These records were used to estimate the potential plant species richness for the Korean Peninsula, including North Korea, which has limited survey data. CQ Ground Truth:
To estimate species richness in South Korea, we used 183,854 occurrence records of
vascular plants, comprising 1574 species from South Korea‚Äôs Third National Ecosystem
Survey data (National Ecosystem Survey data are available at http://ecobank.nie.re.kr
(accessed on 24 June 2021)). Most species observations were recorded between 2006 and
2012. Evaluating the habitat suitability for all species located in South Korea would be
ideal for determining the potential species richness, but we required a minimum number
of 10 occurrence records for use in modeling, since small sample sizes affect the reliability
of statistical analyses [36,37]. The observation records for the 1574 species ranged from 10
to 921. We downloaded 19 bioclimatic variables at a grid resolution of 30-arcseconds (‚âà900
√ó 900 m at the equator) from the WorldClim (http://worldclim.org/ (accessed on 24 June
2021); [38]), soil variables from the Harmonized World Soil Database at a resolution of 30
arcseconds [39], and digital elevation model (DEM) with a 90 m resolution from the SRTM (http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org/)

CQ Ground Truth:
Among the various types of DL architectures, multilayer perceptron (MLP) is the
most practical and typical type of feedforward neural network and is effective for solving
regression problems [62]. However, MLP is now deemed insufficient for modern advanced
computer vision tasks. As an alternative, there is increased interest in convolutional
neural networks (CNNs), which are more effective at analyzing image data [63], since they
use spatial information and sparsely (partially) connected layers instead of MLP‚Äôs fully
connected layers. Although we used co-registered MODIS-derived NDVI and LAI images
collected in 2009 as inputs, there were many missing values at different pixel locations and
times due to high cloud cover. In CNN architecture, these missing values could hinder both
model training and proper inference. Therefore, in consideration of our data characteristics
and the objectives of this study, pixel-wise MLP was used to estimate species richness.
Multilayer perception comprises more than one perceptron, which consists of an input
layer to receive the signal, an output layer that makes a decision, and one in between those
two, and is capable of learning any continuous mapping function from the hierarchical
or multilayered structure of the networks.

CQ: Are there transformations or augmentations applied to the input data?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The provided context does not mention any transformations or augmentations applied to the input data.
CQ Ground Truth:
In this study, we used the 16-day composite NDVI product (MOD13A1 and MYD13A1)
at a resolution of 15 arcseconds and a combined 8-day composite LAI product (MCD15A2)
at 15 arcseconds. However, since the MCD15A2 data contain many missing values because
of high cloud cover, and to match the temporal resolution of the NDVI product, we
converted them to 16-day composite images. To be consistent with the species richness
results in South Korea, these NDVI and LAI data were then resampled at a spatial resolution
of 30 arcseconds. The data were downloaded from the Land Processes Distributed Active
Archive Center (LP DAAC; https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/ (accessed on 24 June 2021)) and
processed using the MODIS Reprojection Tool to convert the map projection and to create
mosaic images. To cover the entire Korean Peninsula, 3 images (h27v04, h27v05, and
h28v05 of MODIS‚Äôs Sinusoidal Tile Grid) were composited.

PSRDL) was calculated as 10.21, indicating that the proposed model slightly underestimated
the potential plant species richness compared with the reference S-SDMs species richness,
but the differences were small and may be handled by adjusting the slope and offset
parameters in post-processing if necessary. A remarkable Pearson‚Äôs correlation coefficient
(0.98) was achieved.

CQ LLM Answer Processed: The deep learning model used in the pipeline is a multilayer perceptron (MLP) architecture. It is a type of feedforward neural network that is effective for solving regression problems. It comprises an input layer, an output layer, and one or more hidden layers in between. The network architecture of MLP used in this study is illustrated in Figure 3 of the document.
CQ Ground Truth:
Among the various types of DL architectures, multilayer perceptron (MLP) is the
most practical and typical type of feedforward neural network and is effective for solving
regression problems [62]. However, MLP is now deemed insufficient for modern advanced
computer vision tasks. As an alternative, there is increased interest in convolutional
neural networks (CNNs), which are more effective at analyzing image data [63], since they
use spatial information and sparsely (partially) connected layers instead of MLP‚Äôs fully
connected layers. Although we used co-registered MODIS-derived NDVI and LAI images
collected in 2009 as inputs, there were many missing values at different pixel locations and
times due to high cloud cover. In CNN architecture, these missing values could hinder both
model training and proper inference. Therefore, in consideration of our data characteristics
and the objectives of this study, pixel-wise MLP was used to estimate species richness.
Multilayer perception comprises more than one perceptron, which consists of an input
layer to receive the signal, an output layer that makes a decision, and one in between those
two, and is capable of learning any continuous mapping function from the hierarchical
or multilayered structure of the networks. Figure 3 illustrates the network architecture of
MLP used in this study.

CQ: How was the model selected for a specific task?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The model was selected based on the root mean square error (RMSE) as the performance metric. The feature importance shows the extent to which the model performance decreased with random shuffling. The feature with the greatest significance in the species richness retrievals was determined using a statistical feature importance test (SFIT). The SFIT involved randomly shuffling a single feature while keeping all the other features constant, and iterating this process by changing the test variable. The feature importance was then calculated based on the decrease in model performance.
CQ Ground Truth:
Due to the unique characteristics of neural networks, which solve problems by ex-
ploiting the hidden relationships inherent in multiple input variables, it was difficult to
physically quantify the importance of the input variables. As an alternative, we performed
a statistical feature importance test (SFIT) to explain which feature had the greatest sig-
nificance in the species richness retrievals and to determine the optimized features in
an operational retrieval system. For the SFIT, a single feature was randomly shuffled,
while all the other features were kept constant. We iterated this process by changing the
test variable. The feature importance shows the extent to which the model performance
decreased with random shuffling. In this study, we used the root mean square error (RMSE)
as the performance metric.

CQ: What were the considerations in the model selection process?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The model selection process considered the use of macro-ecological models and stacking species distribution models (S-SDMs) to estimate species richness. The S-SDMs approach was chosen because it combines the predictions of each species‚Äô SDM to estimate species richness, and probability-based stacking produced unbiased richness that is closer to the true species richness. The model was then validated using independent tree plot datasets from the Korea Forest Service.
CQ Ground Truth:
Several modeling approaches, including macro-ecological models [50] and stacking
species distribution models (S-SDMs) [51], have been proposed for estimating species
richness. As many global species databases, such as the Global Biodiversity Information
Facility (GBIF; www.gbif.org (accessed on 24 June 2021)), eBird (https://ebird.org (accessed
on 24 June 2021) [52]), and iNaturalist (www.inaturalist.org (accessed on 24 June 2021)),
provide species‚Äô occurrence data [14,16], S-SDMs which combine the predictions of each
species‚Äô SDM to estimate species richness have become a common strategy in recent
studies [53]. Although there is still no agreement as to how to stack each species‚Äô predictions,
many studies have found that probability-based (raw SDM results ranging from 0 to 1)
stacking produced unbiased richness that is closer to the true species richness.

CQ: How many models are used in the pipeline?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The pipeline uses two models: a deep learning (DL) model and a species distribution model (SDM). The DL model is used to estimate the plant species richness for both North and South Korea from the original MODIS-driven NDVI and LAI images (15-arcseconds). The SDM model is used to estimate the potential plant species richness of South Korea by combining the probability-based SDM results of the 1574 species.
CQ Ground Truth:
we evaluated our two model results, S-SDMs and DL species richness, by
comparing the species richness obtained from independent tree plot datasets from the
Korea Forest Service. We estimated the potential plant species richness of South Korea by combining the
probability-based SDM results of the 1574 species.

CQ Ground Truth:
Studies that have investigated combinations of remote sensing and machine learning ap-
proaches to represent biodiversity include Lopatin et al. [29], who modeled vascular plant
species richness for trees, shrubs, and herbs using 12 airborne LiDAR-derived variables.
They compared the suitability of random forest (RF) and a generalized linear model (GLM),
and found that the GLM had better performance.

derived from S-SDMs. At each pixel location where no missing values existed, we obtained
approximately 500,000 samples of x and y in South Korea for model training and testing. To develop a geographically more robust estimation model due to the lack of survey
data in North Korea, stacked species richness training data for South Korea were divided
into quadrants (NE, NW, SE, and SW). For each quadrant of South Korea, we developed 4
MLPs using 3 subsets as the training set and the other set as the testing set.

CQ: Are there optimization algorithms or learning rate schedules used during training?

CQ Ground Truth:
We chose the RMSprop stochastic descent
optimizer with the default parameters [64], and a rectified linear unit (ReLU) as a nonlinear
activation function because of its promising performance in the literature [65]. Dropout
layers with a rate of 0.2 were added to each hidden layer to prevent model overfitting [66].
The L1 loss function, also known as the least absolute error, was used because it is not
sensitive to outliers and is intuitive.

CQ: What metrics are used to evaluate the model?

CQ: Did the authors use different metrics for different problems?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: Yes, the authors used different metrics for different problems. For the statistical feature importance test (SFIT), they used the root mean square error (RMSE) as the performance metric. For the independent validation of species richness, they calculated the overall correlation and local correlations between the species richness from the independent datasets and the results from the S-SDMs and DL species richness model. For direct comparisons, the model results were used in Ô¨Åtting and validating a model, respectively. They calculated the AUC for each bivariate model, and the AUC (area under the curve) was used to calculate Somers‚Äô D for weighting all the possible bivariate models. Somers‚Äô D is D = 2 √ó (AUC‚Äî0. 5), and bivariate models with a Somers‚Äô D lower than 0 (i. e. , AUC < 0. 5) were not used to build the ensemble range models. Finally, the suitability of the species was averaged by constructing the ensembles of bivariate models 5 times. For the species with 50 or more occurrence records, they used all 8 predictor variables and Ô¨Åtted the models 5 times using k-fold cross-validation with k = 5. They averaged the 5 results for the Ô¨Ånal suitability result for each species.
CQ Ground Truth: In this study, we used the root mean square error (RMSE) as the performance metric. We adopted the approach of using an ensemble of bivariate models for species with less than 50 occurrence records. In our study, we had 8 predictor variables, so the number of all possible bivariate predictor combinations was 28. We divided the occurrence records randomly in half and the portions of the data were used in fitting and validating a model, respectively. We calculated the AUC for each bivariate model, and the AUC (area under the curve) was used to calculate Somers‚Äô D for weighting all the possible bivariate models. Somers‚Äô D is D = 2 √ó (AUC‚Äî0.5), and bivariate models with a Somers‚Äô D lower than 0 (i.e., AUC < 0.5) were not used to build the ensemble range models [48]. Finally, the suitability of the species was averaged by constructing the ensembles of bivariate models 5 times. For the species with 50 or more occurrence records, we used all 8 predictor variables and fitted the models 5 times using k-fold cross-validation [49] with k = 5. We averaged the 5 results for the final suitability result for each species.

CQ: How are these annotations or labels used in the model?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The annotations or labels are used in the model as the target variable, which is the variable that the model is trying to predict. In this case, the annotations or labels are the species richness values for each grid cell. The model uses these values to learn the relationship between the input variables (such as NDVI and LAI) and the target variable, and then uses this relationship to predict the species richness for new, unseen data.
CQ Ground Truth: Finally, we evaluated our two model results, S-SDMs and DL species richness, by comparing the species richness obtained from independent tree plot datasets from the Korea Forest Service [72]. We calculated species richness using grids with a 10 km resolution after sensitivity analysis at different resolutions. We then calculated the overall correlation and local correlations between the species richness from the independent datasets and the results from the S-SDMs and DL species richness model. For direct comparisons, the model results were resampled at 10 km by pooling a median value of the corresponding pixels within a 10 km grid and comparing them with the results using the independent datasets. To calculate the local correlations, we defined a 3 √ó 3 square focal area (30 km √ó 30 km) for each grid, using a moving window to define the spatial ranges for correlations.

CQ: What predictions or classifications are generated by the deep learning model?
CQ LLM Answer Processed: The deep learning model generates predictions of potential plant species richness for the Korean Peninsula, including North Korea, which has limited survey data. It does this by combining the suitability predictions of 1574 species using species distribution models and multitemporal remote sensing data. The model is able to estimate potential plant species richness over the entire Korean Peninsula at a higher resolution than in previous efforts and identify which variables at which time periods are more important for estimating plant species richness. The deep learning model used in this study is a pixel-wise multilayer perceptron (MLP) which is a type of feedforward neural network that is effective for solving regression problems.
CQ Ground Truth: SDMs define the suitable environmental conditions needed for a species, and its range, by using environmental variables extracted at known species locations. SDMs have been used to estimate species richness by combining the predictions of each species‚Äô modeled range. To accomplish this goal, plant species richness in South Korea was estimated by combining the suitability predictions of 1574 species using species distribution models. To estimate potential plant species richness patterns for North Korea, a state-of-the-art DL approach was used to develop a species richness retrieval model by integration of the surveyed and estimated richness information collected in South Korea and multitemporal remote sensing data.
